32. Spectral tubes containing <u>carbonic acid<\u>
instead of oxide of carbon gave essentially 
the same spectra. The increased quantity 
of oxygen of the decomposed gas may be 
observed by means of the interposed jar.
In such tubes there was no carbon deposited 
not even after a long passage of the discharge.
33. All compound gases enclosed in our 
spectral tubes are decomposed by the heat 
produced by the discharge of Ruhmkorff’s
large induction coil, but instantly after 
the discharge passes the recomposition 
takes place. The <s>d<\s>[r]ecomposition is prevented 
only by a sudden cooling of the elementary 
gases obtained by the decomposition. Thus,
for instance, spectral tubes containing <u>cyanogen<\u>
are scarcely fitted for observation, the in
terior surface of their capillary part being 
instantaneously blackened by the deposited carbon.
No <s>compound of carbon with <\s> carburetted hydrogen 
resists to final decomposition by the passing 
current. We add only a few observations 
made by means of spectral tubes.

drogen and an imperfect spectrum of vapour 
of carbon, especially the brightest lines of
